title: The best airline credit cards of August 2025
description: With so many credit cards that earn airline points and miles, we’ve picked our favorites that not only rack up rewards but give you access to some great perks.
content:
CNN Underscored reviews financial products based on their overall value. We may receive a commission through our affiliate partners if you apply and are approved for a product, but our reporting is always independent and objective. This may impact how links appear on this site. This site does not include all financial companies or all available financial offers. Terms apply to American Express benefits and offers. Enrollment may be required for select American Express benefits and offers. Visit americanexpress.com to learn more.

There are dozens of credit cards on the US market that earn airline miles. But which among those are the best airline credit cards? The answer depends on what you’re looking for in terms of benefits and future travel, as well as which airline or airlines you fly most often. We’ve analyzed all the cards out there and picked our favorites, so you can make a choice based on the rewards the cards can earn you and the perks you get, both when you’re flying and when you aren’t.

Dive into the details of the best airline cards with us to see how they stack up.

Should you have an airline credit card?

Airline-branded cards typically offer perks with that airline and earn miles in its loyalty program, with a multiplier for each dollar spent on purchases with the carrier. The higher the annual fee, the more valuable the airline-specific perks. For example, a card without an annual fee may offer elevated earnings on spending with the airline but no free checked baggage or early boarding. Conversely, an airline’s top co-branded card with an annual fee in the hundreds may offer access to the airline’s lounges as well as other benefits. Often, airline cards come with an accelerated path to elite status with that airline too.

That said, airline cards only make sense for people who fly or plan to fly a given airline often enough. For those who don’t but still want to earn points that can be redeemed for travel, general travel rewards cards may make more sense. Those cards earn points that can be transferred to airlines and hotels or redeemed on the card issuer’s own travel portal, and they often come with travel protections like insurance for delays or lost luggage.

The choice boils down to loyalty to an airline versus earning credit card points that are more flexible than airline miles. Once you’ve earned a mile with Delta, for instance, it can only be redeemed for travel on Delta itself or its partners, but if you’ve earned an American Express point, you can transfer it to a vast number of airlines.

With that in mind, let’s look at our picks among airline cards and travel cards that earn points transferrable to airlines.

You might be surprised to see a card without an airline’s name in this list, but the Chase Sapphire Preferred® Card earns its place here thanks to the flexibility of Chase Ultimate Rewards points.

This card won’t get you free checked bags or special privileges on any airline, nor does it provide lounge access. But it will let you accumulate 2 points per every dollar spent on all travel, 5 points on all travel booked through the Chase Travel℠ portal and 3 points on dining, among other bonus reward categories. You’ll then be able to redeem those points for flights, including in premium cabins, which may come with lounge access, free checked luggage and other perks as part of the ticket.

The more flexible option is to redeem your Chase points through the Chase Travel portal. When you redeem this way, you can book any flight without worrying about award availability or blackout dates. If you can normally pay for it with cash, then you can pay for it with points this way.

You’ll get at least 1 cent per point when you have the Chase Sapphire Preferred and redeem your rewards this way, and you’ll even earn airline miles for the flight because airlines consider these tickets as regular airfare, not award redemption. But you can do better than that: If you opened your Chase Sapphire Preferred account after June 23, 2025, you can take advantage of a feature called Points Plus. When you see a Points Plus icon in the Chase Travel portal, your points are worth more when redeemed for that particular itinerary: up to 1.5x on hotels and flights with select airlines, and up to 1.75x on premium cabin tickets on select airlines. If your account was opened before June 23, points earned before Oct. 26 of this year can be redeemed at 1.25 cents per point until Oct. 26, 2027, and for 1 cent after that. Or, legacy cardmembers can also redeem their points for an increased value through the Points Plus option if it serves as a better redemption value.

But there’s another option. You can instead transfer your points to any of Chase’s 11 airline partners, including Southwest Airlines, JetBlue, United Airlines, British Airways, Emirates and Air Canada, or three hotel partners: IHG, Marriott and Hyatt.

Chase points transfer at a 1-to-1 ratio — meaning you’ll get 1,000 airline miles for every 1,000 Chase points you transfer — and you can then book using the miles or points in that airline or hotel program. However, you’ll only be able to book seats that are available for award redemptions, which usually doesn’t include every flight.

Why would you book this way when you can get any flight using the first option? Because you can potentially get a lot more value for your points when you transfer them, especially if you’re looking to fly internationally in a first- or business-class cabin. That’s why frequent flyer website The Points Guy values Ultimate Rewards points at 2.05 cents apiece.

The annual fee on the Chase Sapphire Preferred is a relatively low $95 a year. Especially if you’re a beginner, paying less than $100 for a travel credit card is a great way to learn more about the various airline partner programs.

Even with a low annual fee, you’ll find that many useful travel insurance benefits come with the Chase Sapphire Preferred. For example, when you pay for travel with the card, you’ll be covered if your trip is canceled for any covered reason, up to $10,000 per person and $20,000 per trip. You’ll also be reimbursed for any covered out-of-pocket expenses, up to $500 per person, if your flight is delayed by at least 12 hours or requires an overnight stay.

Despite a very high $795 annual fee, the Chase Sapphire Reserve® comes with several travel perks, including a $300 yearly travel credit, a $120 Lyft credit, complimentary Priority Pass Select airport lounge access and more. Like the Sapphire Preferred, it isn’t an airline card per se, but it earns points that can be turned into flights on a vast number of airlines.

We’re including it in this article because it’s the best card when it comes to travel protections. In fact, it’s the only card that offers all seven major types of coverage: trip cancellation/interruption insurance, trip delay reimbursement, lost luggage reimbursement, baggage delay insurance, rental car protection, travel accident insurance and emergency evacuation assistance.

When it comes to redeeming credit card rewards for air travel, the Chase Sapphire Reserve works similarly to the Chase Sapphire Preferred but with a few key differences.

Both cards earn Ultimate Rewards points, so you can redeem them the same way: at a fixed rate through the Chase travel portal or by transferring them to Chase’s partners at a 1-to-1 ratio. The big difference is that your points are worth up to 2 cents apiece when you redeem them via the Chase portal with the Sapphire Reserve using Points Boost, where it’s available. On all other purchases on Chase Travel, you’ll get 1.5 cents per point (for cardmembers who opened their card prior to June 23, 2025 on points earned before Oct. 26, 2025, and redeemed until Oct. 26, 2027; after that, they’ll be valued 1 cent.)

The Chase Sapphire Reserve also offers a great earning rate on airfare and hotels booked directly with providers, where you’ll earn 4 points for every dollar. For purchases on Chase Travel, you’ll get an exceptional 8x points. You’ll also earn 3x on dining worldwide, making this a great card for frequent travelers — and one that doesn’t tie them into a single airline’s ecosystem.

The Platinum Card from American Express: Best for luxury travel

The Platinum Card® from American Express (see rates and fees) also isn’t tied to a specific airline, but earns points that can be redeemed directly for any flight or transferred to many airlines and hotels, but with a set of partners that’s different from Chase’s credit cards.

When it comes to earning points on airfare, the Amex Platinum has the highest earning rate of any credit card on our list. You’ll earn 5 points for every dollar spent when booking directly with the airline or with American Express Travel® (up to $500,000 on these purchases per calendar year). That’s more than the 4 points per dollar you’ll earn with the Chase Sapphire Reserve, but you’ll earn bonus points on many other travel purchases with the Chase card, while the Amex Platinum only earns those 5 points per dollar on airfare, as well as hotels and flights booked through American Express Travel.

But the Amex Platinum is best known for its luxury perks. For starters, just by being a card member, you’ll have complimentary access to thousands of airport lounges around the world, including the exclusive American Express Centurion Lounges, Delta Sky Clubs when flying Delta (10 Sky Club day passes per Medallion year) and Priority Pass airport lounges (but not Priority Pass restaurants, and enrollment is required for Priority Pass).

Card members also get complimentary Gold elite status with the Hilton and Marriott hotel chains, which can get you a late checkout, bonus points when staying on a paid rate, space-available upgraded rooms and complimentary breakfast at select properties (enrollment is required). You’ll also have elite status with three car rental companies: Hertz (President’s Circle), Avis (Preferred Plus) and National (Executive).

Now, the Amex Platinum doesn’t come cheap, with an annual fee of $695 per year. Fortunately, the many travel perks, along with yearly credits, can help offset the fee if you can take advantage of them.

When it comes to transferring points, American Express has a wider selection than Chase, with 17 airlines and three hotel partners. In particular, American Express Membership Rewards® are the only credit card points issued in the US that transfer to Delta Air Lines.

With seven different Delta credit cards available — four personal and three business — there’s a Delta card for all types of flyers. The Delta SkyMiles® Gold American Express Card will likely suit occasional Delta flyers the best. It has an introductory annual fee of $0 for the first year, and then a $150 annual fee starting at your first renewal (see rates and fees), so you can try out the card for a year to see if it’s right for you.

You’ll earn 2 Delta SkyMiles per dollar on purchases made directly with Delta with the Delta Gold Amex, as well as at restaurants worldwide (including takeout and delivery in the U.S.) and U.S. supermarkets. You’ll also get priority boarding on Delta flights, a free checked bag when flying Delta and 20% off Delta in-flight purchases.

Right now, the Amex Delta Gold also has a welcome offer of 70,000 SkyMiles after you spend $2,000 in the first six months, an exceptional number of miles for that spend. For reference, The Points Guy values 70,000 Delta miles at $840.

Also, if you spend $10,000 on the Delta Gold Amex card in a calendar year, you’ll earn a Delta flight credit worth up to $200. So, if you’re able to spend this much on your credit card each year, that alone will more than make up for its annual fee.

However, if you expect to be in the air a lot more often, you might instead want to look at the Delta SkyMiles® Platinum American Express Card or the Delta SkyMiles® Reserve American Express Card. Both of these higher-end cards will help you earn Delta elite status quicker and come with more Delta perks, including an annual companion certificate after your first year.

The Delta Reserve card also provides access to Delta SkyClub and Amex Centurion Lounges when flying Delta. Of course, both of these premium Delta credit cards come with significantly higher annual fees, so the benefits may or may not justify the cost depending on how often you travel.

The New United Explorer Card: Best for United flyers

If you’re a United frequent flyer like CNN Underscored travel editor Kyle Olsen, you could consider The New United℠ Explorer Card. It comes with no annual fee for the first year, then a $150 fee starting in the second year, allowing you to essentially try it out for no cost while determining if it works for your spending and travel habits.

With this card, you’ll earn 2 miles for every dollar you spend on United, as well as at restaurants (including eligible delivery services) and on hotel stays booked directly with the hotel, plus 1 mile per dollar on everything else. That’s not bad, but keep in mind that the Chase Sapphire Preferred earns 2 points per dollar on dining and all travel, and you can transfer Chase points to United.

That’s why the real reason to have the New United Explorer Card is taking advantage of its perks, and not only when flying on United. Unique among airline credit at this annual fee level, it will reimburse you for up to $120 for a Global Entry or TSA PreCheck membership application fee. It also offers primary insurance coverage for rental cars, another unique feature among its peer airline cards.

You’ll get priority boarding and earn 25% back on in-flight purchases when you’re on a United flight, and you can check your first bag for free (as well as one for a traveling companion). The card also comes with two United Club lounge day passes per year.

Another interesting aspect for an airline card, it also offers an incentive to fly on a different carrier. You’ll get up to $100 statement credit per year on flights booked directly with JSX, a company offering flights that depart from private terminals on smaller jets, on which you can earn United’s own MileagePlus miles.

If Southwest is your airline of choice, you’re aware that the biggest US carrier by domestic passengers has recently done away with its unique business model. Southwest has introduced assigned seating, premium seats and fees for checked baggage, like all other airlines in the country. (Assigned and premium seating will officially begin on Jan. 27, 2026, but baggage fees are already in effect.)

The airline has a spate of co-branded cards that can circumvent those fees, though. The Southwest Rapid Rewards® Priority Credit Card is the most expensive of the Southwest personal credit cards, with an annual fee of $229. Even with that annual cost, we chose it for this list because it comes with the most benefits, which are especially useful under the airline’s new bag and seating policies.

The Southwest Priority card comes with a first checked bag free for the card holder and up to eight additional passengers on the same reservation. At $35 per checked bag per person, this benefit alone could surpass the cost of the annual fee. Beginning Jan. 27 of next year, it will also lets the card holder select a Preferred seat with more legroom at no charge, when available. Also on the same date, card holders and up to eight passengers on the same reservation will board early, with group 5.

Further, the points you earn on the Southwest Priority card — including the sign-up bonus — count as qualifying points toward the Southwest Companion Pass, and the card also awards an annual boost of 10,000 Companion Pass-qualifying points. Having the pass can save you thousands of dollars, as it allows a companion to fly with you for free (plus the minimal costs of taxes and fees) for the rest of the year in which you earned the pass, plus the entire following year.

The card also will get you 7,500 bonus points each anniversary year starting with your second year as a card holder, 25% back on inflight purchases like drinks and Wi-Fi, and 2,500 tier-qualifying points (TQPs) toward A-List status for every $5,000 spent in purchases annually, meaning you’ll get to elite status on Southwest faster.

This could be a good card for people who spend a decent amount on gas and dining out, since the card earns 2 points per dollar on gas stations and restaurants. On Southwest purchases, it earns 4x.

For the occasional American Airlines flyer, the Citi®/AAdvantage® Platinum Select® World Elite Mastercard® is a great card, especially since there’s no annual fee for the first year, then only $99 per year thereafter. While it isn’t the best card to use on everyday spending since it earns 2x points only on restaurants and gas stations, as well as American Airlines purchases, you can save a lot of money with it on baggage fees.

All Citi AAdvantage Platinum card holders get a free checked bag on domestic American flights for not only themselves but up to four additional companions on the same reservation. With baggage fees starting at $35 per bag, a family of four all checking a bag can save $280 by flying just one round trip a year. That’s almost three times the annual fee.

Card holders also board before all other passengers in Main Cabin and get a 25% savings on in-flight food and beverage purchases on American Airlines flights. Spending $20,000 in purchases during the card membership year and renewing the credit triggers a $125 American Airlines flight discount.

Also, like other mid-tier airline cards, the AA Platinum Select has no foreign transaction fees.

Now, if you fly American regularly, you might prefer the Citi®/AAdvantage® Executive World Elite Mastercard® instead, since it comes with an Admirals Club lounge membership and additional benefits. But the card isn’t cheap at $595 a year, so it’s probably best only for those who expect to be on an American plane at least monthly.

JetBlue Plus Card: Best for JetBlue flyers

JetBlue is only the seventh US airline by passengers carried, but it has a large share in major markets like New York City and Boston. People who fly it often will find value in the JetBlue Plus credit card, which earns a remarkable 6 points per dollar on JetBlue flights. It’s not the top card for everyday spending, with 2 points per dollar at restaurants and grocery stores and 1 point per dollar on everything else, but it comes with some perks that can improve your experience when flying JetBlue.

You and up to three companions on the same reservation get a free checked bag when flying JetBlue, which can easily save you hundreds of dollars with just one trip. And while this card comes with a $99 annual fee, you’ll earn 5,000 bonus points each year starting with your first account anniversary (meaning a year after you first get the card). These 5,000 points are worth about $72 according to The Points Guy, which offsets more than two-thirds of the cost of the card. And right now, the card has a remarkable welcome offer of 80,000 points after spending just $1,000 and paying the annual fee within 90 days from account opening. That amount of miles is worth $1,160.

A notable feature of JetBlue points is that they can be pooled with family and friends, which makes it easier to hit the critical mass needed for a redemption. With this card, you’ll also get 10% of your points back after you redeem for and travel on a JetBlue-operated award flight.

Capital One Venture Credit Card: Best for ease of use

The Capital One Venture Rewards Credit Card takes the cake when it comes to flexibility. This straightforward travel card earns 2 miles for every dollar you spend on it — no need to worry about bonus categories. You can then redeem your miles for any travel purchase at 1 cent per mile, which means you’re getting a 2% return on all your purchases, which is comparable to the best credit card options on the market.

Redeeming your miles is incredibly easy using the Capital One Venture’s “Purchase Eraser” feature. All you have to do is charge any travel-related purchase to your Venture card, and then go online within 90 days and choose to redeem your miles for that transaction instead of paying for it with cash.

Now, if you’re an expert when it comes to frequent flyer programs, you can also transfer your Capital One miles to 19 different travel partners, including British Airways, Air Canada, Avianca and Wyndham Rewards. You’ll need to do your homework if you go this route, but you can potentially get a lot more value for your miles, which is why frequent flyer website The Points Guy values Capital One miles at 1.85 cents each.

The following FAQs have been answered by CNN Underscored senior money editor Alberto Riva.

At CNN Underscored, we evaluate cards based on overall value, not just flashy welcome offers, by focusing on long-term benefits like reward rates, perks and fees. CNN Underscored senior money editor Alberto Riva is a very frequent flyer who covers around 100,000 miles a year in the air and currently holds seven airline credit cards. He’s earned and redeemed vast numbers of air miles and credit card points. His credit card recommendations are based on real-world experience and years covering travel and finance.

shortSummary: The best airline credit cards, including Chase Sapphire Preferred, offer flexible rewards and benefits with airline-branded cards, but prioritize airline-specific rewards over broader travel benefits and flexibility.

scraped_sources.text:
The end of an era is official for Southwest Airlines passengers.
On Monday, the airline announced a start date for its new assigned seating, which will bring the airline’s longstanding open-seat boarding tradition to an end.
For flights beginning on January 27, 2026, passengers will have options for seat selection at the time of booking, Southwest said in its announcement.
“Our Customers want more choice and greater control over their travel experience,” said Tony Roach, Southwest executive vice president of customer and brand, in a news release.
“Assigned seating unlocks new opportunities for our Customers — including the ability to select Extra Legroom seats — and removes the uncertainty of not knowing where they will sit in the cabin,” Roach said.
Various fare bundles will offer some options for seat selection during booking. Different types of seats — Extra Legroom, Preferred and Standard — will also appear as part of those bundles.
The assigned-seat era will also usher in a new group-based boarding process.
Extra Legroom seats will have priority in boarding Groups 1-2.
Premium fares and loyalty program members and credit cardholders will board earlier in the process. Details are available on the airline’s website.
The airline announced its plans to end its free-for-all seating arrangement last summer.
The change allows the low-fare carrier to charge a premium for some of the seats on its planes to better compete with legacy carriers American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines. Those airlines generate much of their revenue by charging more for premium seating.
CNN’s Chris Isidore contributed to this report.

argos_summary: CNN Underscored reviews various airline credit cards, highlighting their benefits and suitability based on individual travel habits. The article discusses options like the Chase Sapphire Preferred and Reserve cards, which offer flexible point redemption, and specific airline cards such as the Delta SkyMiles Gold and United Explorer cards, which provide airline-specific perks. Additionally, it notes Southwest Airlines' upcoming transition to assigned seating starting January 27, 2026, allowing for seat selection and a new boarding process.
